Yeah like do you really need to double the amount of card rewards from a battle?
whomever designed hexa thought they needed to

This card is absolutely and completely broken. It emulates the effect of prayer wheel (one of the strongest relics in the game IMO), but the critical difference is that it also gives you a second card reward in elite and boss fights. Elite fights are more likely to give you uncommons and rares, and boss fights are guaranteed to show you all rares. Getting to look at 2 different rare card rewards of 3 cards each at the same time is insane, it gives you a huge amount of control and selection over how your deck will look, and lets you hunt for synergies, as well as take setup/payoff cards simultaneously. Now granted, you do need to draw and pay for 3rd seal, and you didn't draw a more useful card that could block or deal damage that turn, so prayer wheel does have an edge in some respects. Still, you have afterlife, sword of night, and shield of night, all of which let you cheat on energy costs, as well as first seal that can help heal you back up at the end of fights.

One of the real strengths of third seal is that it is extremely helpful in finding the rest of the seals, particularly 5 and 6 due to the increased rare chance from getting two card rewards in elite fights, and higher rare chance in general due to seeing more commons. Speaking of seeing more commons, this also gives you way more chances than normal to see the holy trinity (ghost shield, sword of night, shield of night), and every single copy of ghost shield you find increases your win percentage significantly. A single third seal (especially early in a run) will let you dramatically improve the number of cards you get to see, which will let you craft a very cohesive deck.

Let's talk relic synergies. Singing bowl can give you huge amounts of sustain and max HP, any of the egg relics will combine very well with the extra card rewards, mummified hand and  bird faced urn can help offset the tempo loss, while question card lets you see an insane number of cards.
https://slay-the-spire.fandom.com/wiki/Card_Rewards

embeds.title: Card Rewards
embeds.description: Card Rewards are a type of reward that the player receives after defeating an enemy, elite, or boss. Each card reward allows the player to choose one of three cards, but the player can also skip...

messages.content: Definitely a top 5 hexa card, I'd say probably #4, better than burning touch but can't beat the night cards and ghost shield
It's hard to compare meta-scaling cards to normal cards, since technically you could make the argument that since it lets you see more ghost shields it could be #2?
it's pretty insane yeah
Hexa feels like an almost balanced character, but also with like 5 cards that are "modded character cards"
I wonder if the 4 hexa commons and this got nerfed pretty hard how hexa would manage, I don't see it doing well

I think I would actually put third seal over ghost shield. Ghost shield can't let you acquire tons of additional rares, it can't build broken seal, it can't help you find late game scaling solutions. And ghost shield can't give you more opportunities to draft itself. Hexaghost would definitely be in a rough state if the 4 commons and this were changed, though I think that afterlife as a whole is a big chunk of their power budget right now. 

Clunky as it would be, this card might need to be changed to only work in hallway fights, or maybe hallway and elite fights. The other way to nerf it would be to make it cost 2, which is much cleaner. I think the effect is absolutely powerful enough to be worth spending 2 energy on.

Yeah no, I could see an argument for it being over sword of night and maybe even shield of night as well, but hexa's defense rides on ghost shield. I've had so many A20 builds where I just take 0 damage after turn 1 of any fight because I have so much block.
And saying it is BETTER than ghost shield because it can get you more ghost shield... what? It's better than ghost shield because it lets you abuse ghost shield more often?
Let's try this. Play a few runs where you never take 3rd seal. Weaker on average but you'll survive. Now try playing a few runs where you don't take ghost shield.
Now you have to take so much more block to account for the turns you didn't carry your extra block.

Third seal is extremely damn good, I still think it would be better on most other characters. Hexa's rare pool is honestly just alright, it's mostly the commons but you normally should already get enough from just playing the game normally.

And also speaking of that. Ghost shield is a common, this is uncommon. There is 30+ uncommon cards on most characters' kit. There is usually about 20 commons, and commons are already more likely to show up.
If you take in the rarity as a part of how strong a card is, you'll see why ghost shield works. It is so easy to get.
And ghost shield also lets you abuse shield of night's absurd block numbers as multi-turn block, making hexa so hard to kill once you hit a certain point.
3rd seal is a strong part of hexa, but ghost shield is hexa.
and shield/sword of night are just insane cards, I'd place them narrowly above 3rd seal
without sword of night hexa would be a lot weaker act 1, 13(17) damage for basically 1 cost is insane, that's like some rare card numbers
look at <unload> and <brilliance>. This is that but a common.

embeds.title: Unload
embeds.description:
Rare Attack / 1 :e_green: / The Silent / Slay the Spire

Deal 14 (18) damage.
Discard all non-Attack cards in your hand.

embeds.title: Brilliance
embeds.description:
Rare Attack / 1 :e_purple: / The Watcher / Slay the Spire

Deal 12 (16) damage.
Deals additional damage equal to Mantra :p_mantra: gained this combat.
